所有在美加的手足，香港人真的需要你
所有nba賽事中場休息都有表演
所有美國學校都有表演機會

先播出香港人為何要爭取民主 或 真人演講，香港人為何要抗爭 （學生或女性演講為佳）
後播出 反修例運動的血腥片段
先播出現榮光原曲MV
之後，真人唱英文版 glory to Hong Kong
只需要有當地的管弦樂團 自願幫助, 戴上頭盔眼罩和豬咀， 最重要是；搵足夠的香港留學生 現場領唱

+++++++++++++++++++++++++

向全場觀眾敬禮 或 鞠躬
向全世界願意幫助香港的人 致敬！
用英文大叫：“ 必需成立獨立調查委員會 和 香港真普選"

+++++++++++++++++++++

建議先搵校園多做練習或公開場合表演給美國人看，目標是當地的人！不是香港人；我只是出意見，一切以當地的反應為依歸，隨機應變； 現場反應熱烈後，再邁向電視直播中表現， 電視直播絕不可以出錯

#所有中場休息的表演 應該都有合約/商業贊助， 如果不行，可以嘗試賽前表演 或 其他時間 。 最重要是表演得掌聲，催人熱淚 得到現場觀眾認同，身同感受。 演出就是演出， 觀眾的反應就是一切.

#不要過份控訴警察，西方國家政府/議員/總統十分依賴警察執法……重點是中共的暴和學生的惨，要求即時行動：保護香港人， 我們每一個學生都在死亡邊緣。

# 謹記“不要問：他們可以無動於衷 ，不幫助我們！請先問：為何他們一定要幫助我們？” 我們既要謙虛也要感恩。

# 逢係宣傳都要合乎當地民情 ，同一個廣告在香港大賣未必適合美國， 要“配合”白人的感受 /黑人的接受 /西班牙牙族裔的喜歡 /女性的認同 ，更加要有普世價值 和美國精神，有很多禁忌是外人難以明白。

#就算中美貿易達成一萬個協議，美國人民都會站在香港人這一邊，因為中共就是邪惡的象徵， 問題只是香港人識唔識做！

這位保守黨人權委員會的朋友，呼籲大家tweet Lord Tauriq 同英國外相，解釋點解BNO 應該要平權 🙏 例如比大家一個保障，或者改變一個歷史錯誤等等

我們的留言，是之後國會辯論BNO地位時可以用的材料，已經講到明需要大量留言

就算英文不好，也可以入去講幾句的，麻煩BNO朋友幫幫手啦～

https://mobile.twitter.com/lukedepulford/status/1184738357475266560

quote.msg: 希望唔係口交 真係做
我預佢鳩up。英國佬我真係有保留，佢脫歐可能緊加想痴中國
我反而家覺得脫歐之後英國平權bno既誘因係不減反增，bno撚背後既資源真係唔少野，如果歸晒英係好大補針，對中國又有加速洗香港血既效果，操作得好可以係3贏局面

這位保守黨人權委員會的朋友，呼籲大家tweet
外相 @DominicRaab 同官員 @tariqahmadbt，解釋點解BNO 應該要平權 🙏 例如比大家一個保障，或者改變一個歷史錯誤等等，盡量用自己文句，禮貌陳述事實

我們的留言，是之後國會辯論BNO地位時可以用的材料，發tweet者已經講到明需。要。大。量。留。言。

人家講到明就算英文不好，也可以入去講幾句的，麻煩BNO朋友幫幫手啦～

https://mobile.twitter.com/lukedepulford/status/1184738357475266560

replies.msg:
英國petition 簽呀

https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/264610
推呀

Dear Lord Tariq,

I’m writing on behalf of Hong Kong citizens who value freedom of speech, human rights and democracy, in expressing our concerns regarding the recent status of Hong Kong under the ‘One country, Two systems’ framework since the handover back in 1997.

It has been over 4 months since the start of the protest, and there’s no signs of Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam attempting to compromise and satisfy the 5 demands which have been repeatedly demanded by the protestors. Police brutality is escalating, with suspicious death of supporters of the movement being regarded as suicidal despite numerous evidences have been handover to the government and the Police Force.

With more and more youngsters being arrested and treated in an anti-human way by the Police Force, people of Hong Kong urgently need the help of the British government. By officially condemning and revoke the British citizenship of Carrie Lam and her family members, it may help render down the increasingly tense atmosphere in Hong Kong.

I would also like to draw your attention regarding the issues of British National (Overseas). The nationality has been criticized of abandoning the people who were born and raised in a territory of the UK before the handover. Offering BNO holders a 2nd citizenship will preserve their human rights as a British citizen.

It’s totally understandable that offering BNO holders a 2nd citizenship may raise the concern of leading to a catastrophic consequence to the social structure and national security. It is fair to say that BNO holders need to prove their loyalty and contribution to the United Kingdom before being offered a 2nd citizenship. I would be grateful if Lord Ahmad can examine the possibility of a screening system base on qualifications, language proficiency and their attitude towards values that cherished by the British people, as an evaluation to allow BNO holders in gaining their rights of abode. It’s crucial for the UK government to safeguard its domestic citizens while evaluating contributions that can be made by BNO holders.

The ‘One country, two systems’ is currently under the severe threat of the Communist Party, people of Hong Kong are running out of time and support from international communities can make a significant difference. I wholeheartedly invite Lord Ahmad and his colleagues to pay additional attention to Hong Kong issues base on the obligations embedded in The Sino–British Joint Declaration, and to evaluate the possibility of granting qualified BNO holders to right to abode in the UK in ensuring their personal safety.

quote.msg:
Dear Lord Tariq,

I’m writing on behalf of Hong Kong citizens who value freedom of speech, human rights and democracy, in expressing our concerns regarding the recent status of Hong Kong under the ‘One country, Two systems’ framework since the handover back in 1997.

It has been over 4 months since the start of the protest, and there’s no signs of Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam attempting to compromise and satisfy the 5 demands which have been repeatedly demanded by the protestors. Police brutality is escalating, with suspicious death of supporters of the movement being regarded as suicidal despite numerous evidences have been handover to the government and the Police Force.

With more and more youngsters being arrested and treated in an anti-human way by the Police Force, people of Hong Kong urgently need the help of the British government. By officially condemning and revoke the British citizenship of Carrie Lam and her family members, it may help render down the increasingly tense atmosphere in Hong Kong.

I would also like to draw your attention regarding the issues of British National (Overseas). The nationality has been criticized of abandoning the people who were born and raised in a territory of the UK before the handover. Offering BNO holders a 2nd citizenship will preserve their human rights as a British citizen.

It’s totally understandable that offering BNO holders a 2nd citizenship may raise the concern of leading to a catastrophic consequence to the social structure and national security. It is fair to say that BNO holders need to prove their loyalty and contribution to the United Kingdom before being offered a 2nd citizenship. I would be grateful if Lord Ahmad can examine the possibility of a screening system base on qualifications, language proficiency and their attitude towards values that cherished by the British people, as an evaluation to allow BNO holders in gaining their rights of abode. It’s crucial for the UK government to safeguard its domestic citizens while evaluating contributions that can be made by BNO holders.

The ‘One country, two systems’ is currently under the severe threat of the Communist Party, people of Hong Kong are running out of time and support from international communities can make a significant difference. I wholeheartedly invite Lord Ahmad and his colleagues to pay additional attention to Hong Kong issues base on the obligations embedded in The Sino–British Joint Declaration, and to evaluate the possibility of granting qualified BNO holders to right to abode in the UK in ensuring their personal safety.

Dear Lord Tariq,

I’m writing on behalf of Hong Kong citizens who value freedom of speech, human rights and democracy, in expressing our concerns regarding the recent status of Hong Kong under the ‘One country, Two systems’ framework since the handover back in 1997.

It has been over 4 months since the start of the protest, and there’s no signs of Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam attempting to compromise and satisfy the 5 demands which have been repeatedly demanded by the protestors. Police brutality is escalating, with suspicious death of supporters of the movement being regarded as suicidal despite numerous evidences have been handover to the government and the Police Force.

With more and more youngsters being arrested and treated in an anti-human way by the Police Force, people of Hong Kong urgently need the help of the British government. By officially condemning and revoke the British citizenship of Carrie Lam and her family members, it may help render down the increasingly tense atmosphere in Hong Kong.

I would also like to draw your attention regarding the issues of British National (Overseas). The nationality has been criticized of abandoning the people who were born and raised in a territory of the UK before the handover. Offering BNO holders a 2nd citizenship will preserve their human rights as a British citizen.

It’s totally understandable that offering BNO holders a 2nd citizenship may raise the concern of leading to a catastrophic consequence to the social structure and national security. It is fair to say that BNO holders need to prove their loyalty and contribution to the United Kingdom before being offered a 2nd citizenship. I would be grateful if Lord Ahmad can examine the possibility of a screening system base on qualifications, language proficiency and their attitude towards values that cherished by the British people, as an evaluation to allow BNO holders in gaining their rights of abode. It’s crucial for the UK government to safeguard its domestic citizens while evaluating contributions that can be made by BNO holders.

The ‘One country, two systems’ is currently under the severe threat of the Communist Party, people of Hong Kong are running out of time and support from international communities can make a significant difference. I wholeheartedly invite Lord Ahmad and his colleagues to pay additional attention to Hong Kong issues base on the obligations embedded in The Sino–British Joint Declaration, and to evaluate the possibility of granting qualified BNO holders to right to abode in the UK in ensuring their personal safety.
